1.text: Boast not thyself of to-morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.

2.text: Let another man praise thee, and not thy own mouth; a stranger, and not thy own lips.

3.text: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath is heavier than both.

4.text: Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?

5.text: Open rebuke is better than secret love.

6.text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.

7.text: The full soul lotheth a honey-comb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.

8.text: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place.

9.text: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so doth the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.

10.text: Thy own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbor that is near, than a brother far off.

11.text: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.

12.text: A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.

13.text: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.

14.text: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.

15.text: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.

16.text: Whoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand which bewrayeth itself.

17.text: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.

18.text: He that keepeth the fig-tree shall eat the fruit of it: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honored.

19.text: As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.

20.text: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

21.text: As the fining-pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.

22.text: Though thou shouldst bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet his foolishness will not depart from him.

23.text: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, and look well to thy herds.

24.text: For riches are not for ever: and doth the crown endure to every generation?

25.text: The plant appeareth, and the tender grass showeth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.

26.text: The lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.

27.text: And thou shalt have goats milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for maintenance for thy maidens.
